Exaggerate: The claim made by Trump that he "did phenomenally well" with women voters in the 2016 election could be seen as an exaggeration, as it is contradicted by exit poll data and expert analysis.
Understate: The claim made by Trump fails to acknowledge the fact that he did not win a majority of women voters in the 2016 election. He received only 41% of the women's vote, while 54% voted for Hillary Clinton.
Lack enough support: The claim made by Trump lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up his assertion that he "might have won women" in the election. He does not provide any specific data or analysis to support this claim.
Problematic assumption: Trump's claim assumes that his focus on women and Hillary Clinton's focus on women were the determining factors in winning over women voters. However, political science researchers point out that political party identification is a stronger predictor of vote choice than gender.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim made by Trump ignores the alternative explanation that his success with women voters may have been due to the fact that white women consistently vote Republican, rather than his specific appeal to women as a candidate.
